dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Welcome back to the show, everyone! Wow, what a day, huh? The stock market just went absolutely wild on Thursday.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Welcome back to the show, everyone! Wow, what a day, huh? The stock market just went absolutely wild on Thursday.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it really did, didn't it? I mean, we're talking about a massive surge. The Dow, uh, gained over 1,400 points. That's, like, 5.2% in one afternoon!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it really did, didn't it? I mean, we're talking about a massive surge. The Dow, uh, gained over fourteen hundred points. That's, like, five point two percent in one afternoon!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 5.2%, over 1,400 points, by mid-afternoon on Thursday, while the S&P 500 was down 4.2% and the tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite lost 3.5%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Incredible! And it seems like a lot of that optimism is really buoyed by, well, a couple of things. The Fed's pronouncements, for one, about a rapid economic recovery.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Incredible! And it seems like a lot of that optimism is really buoyed by, well, a couple of things. The Fed's pronouncements, for one, about a rapid economic recovery.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Investors also assessed the Federal Reserves grim update on the economy: The Central Bank forecasted a long recovery, with unemployment set to remain high for years.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Yeah, the Fed came out, and they just sounded super confident, like, "Hey, we're gonna bounce back quick!"
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, the Fed came out, and they just sounded super confident, like, Hey, we're gonna bounce back quick!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Investors also assessed the Federal Reserves grim update on the economy: The Central Bank forecasted a long recovery, with unemployment set to remain high for years.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? And then, uh, investors are also starting to downplay those earlier concerns about a second wave of cases as states reopen. Like, few places that opened up have seen a *huge* spike.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? And then, uh, investors are also starting to downplay those earlier concerns about a second wave of cases as states reopen. Like, few places that opened up have seen a huge spike.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Wall Street is increasingly worried about a second wave of coronavirus infections: Texas, for example, was one of the first states to reopen, but recently reported three consecutive days of record hospitalizations.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. You look at a state like Texas, which was a bit later to reopen, and they actually reported three consecutive days of record low hospitalizations. That's, like, a big deal.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. You look at a state like Texas, which was a bit later to reopen, and they actually reported three consecutive days of record low hospitalizations. That's, like, a big deal.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Texas, for example, was one of the first states to reopen, but recently reported three consecutive days of record hospitalizations.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It really is. And you're seeing that reflected in the stocks that would benefit from a reopening, right? Airlines, retailers, even cruise operators. They're all rallying after lagging for a while.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It really is. And you're seeing that reflected in the stocks that would benefit from a reopening, right? Airlines, retailers, even cruise operators. They're all rallying after lagging for a while.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Stocks that would benefit from a reopeningincluding airlines, retailers and cruise operatorshave all plunged recently, after having led the market rally in the past few weeks.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: But, um, we also saw the weekly jobless claims still increase for the tenth week in a row, right? 1.5 million fewer people, but still a huge number.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But, um, we also saw the weekly jobless claims still increase for the tenth week in a row, right? one point five million fewer people, but still a huge number.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Weekly jobless claims fell for the tenth week in a row on Thursday, with 1.5 million more Americans filing for unemployment during the week ending June 6.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, 1.5 million fewer filed, but still a huge number of filings, to be clear. But the good news is, like, that number *is* declining, and the job market's recovery is actually expected to take just a matter of weeks.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, one point five million fewer filed, but still a huge number of filings, to be clear. But the good news is, like, that number is declining, and the job market's recovery is actually expected to take just a matter of weeks.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While that number continues to decline, millions remain unemployed and the job markets recovery is expected to take years.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, the Fed's pretty bullish on this short recovery then? That's what I'm hearing?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, the Fed's pretty bullish on this short recovery then? That's what I'm hearing?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Super bullish! I mean, Jerome Powell, the Fed chairman, was even talking about, uh, already thinking about raising rates eventually. That's a huge sign of confidence.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Super bullish! I mean, Jerome Powell, the Fed chairman, was even talking about, uh, already thinking about raising rates eventually. That's a huge sign of confidence.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We are not even thinking about thinking about raising rates, Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell confirmed at his press conference on Wednesday.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. That's a big statement. So, like, we're looking at a pretty quick turnaround here, hopefully?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. That's a big statement. So, like, we're looking at a pretty quick turnaround here, hopefully?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: That's the narrative right now. Though, uh, it's not all sunshine and rainbows, is it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's the narrative right now. Though, uh, it's not all sunshine and rainbows, is it?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: What do you mean? Oh, the tech stocks?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: What do you mean? Oh, the tech stocks?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. Big tech shares, like Amazon, Apple, Netflix, Google, they've actually been plunging recently. Kind of undermining the Nasdaq a bit.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. Big tech shares, like Amazon, Apple, Netflix, Google, they've actually been plunging recently. Kind of undermining the Nasdaq a bit.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Shares of Amazon, Apple, Netflix, Microsoft and Google-parent Alphabet have all been soaring recently, boosting the index higher.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, I saw that. It's interesting how investors are, like, rotating out of those big tech winners and into the more traditional reopening plays.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, I saw that. It's interesting how investors are, like, rotating out of those big tech winners and into the more traditional reopening plays.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: With investors rotating out of stocks that would benefit from an economic reopening, big tech shares have made a comeback.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. So, a really interesting shift in focus there. But overall, certainly a much more positive vibe this week.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. So, a really interesting shift in focus there. But overall, certainly a much more positive vibe this week.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The S&P 500 is on track for a third straight day of losses, turning negative for the year after briefly turning positive for 2020 earlier this week.
